The heterogeneous dehydration of monoethanolamine (MEA) to ethylenimine (EI) over solid acids/bases has garnered significant attention in industry because of the importance of EI in fine chemical engineering and the advantage in product separation. Unfortunately, lacking insight into the impacts of acidity/basicity on product selectivity in the reaction hinders the development of high-performance solid acids/bases. To investigate the effect of acidity/basicity, this work employs acid-activated montmorillonite (Acid-MMT) as catalyst and the acidity/basicity is adjusted by adding different acidic/basic oxides and changing preparation conditions. Under the conditions of reaction temperature = 420 °C, GHSV = 5000 h−1, N2/MEA = 19, the optimized Acid-MMT based catalyst modified by Cs2O and P2O5 exhibits a MEA conversion of 86.4% and an EI selectivity of 80.3%. By correlating the catalyst performance with the acidity/basicity, lower amount of acidic/basic sites leads to a higher selectivity of EI via intramolecular dehydration of MEA, while intermolecular dehydration of MEA is inhibited. This is because the intermolecular dehydration reaction is kinetically obstructed by the low acidic/basic amounts, and the parallel intramolecular dehydration reaction becomes kinetically dominated. Furthermore, the catalytic results and the statistical study demonstrate that more balanced amounts between acidic and basic sites favor the intramolecular dehydration reaction. Therefore, we can obtain an effective Cs-P/Acid-MMT catalyst for the selective dehydration of MEA to EI, and propose some solid evidences about the effect of acidity/basicity on product distribution in MEA dehydration over the solid acids/bases. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Monoethanolamine Ethylenimine Dehydration, montmorillonite, acidity/basicity Data availability Data available within the article or its supplementary materials. 1 Introduction Ethylenimine (EI) is an essential intermediate for producing fine chemicals, dyes, and pharmaceuticals. Starting from monoethanolamine (MEA), two commercial processes are currently available for synthesizing EI via the catalytically intramolecular dehydration reaction. The first route, known as the Wenker method [1], is a batch operation of a homogeneously aqueous process by using H2SO4 and NaOH as the catalysts. The second method involves a gas-phase heterogeneous process catalyzed by solid acids/bases [2–5]. Compared to the first method, the solid acids/bases catalyzed gas-phase dehydration of MEA is more attractive due to its environmentally friendly nature. Although the heterogeneous process has already been industrialized for producing EI, more efficient catalyst is pursued for improving the process efficiency, which is still challenged by the complex reaction network of MEA under the relevant reaction conditions. As reported in the reference [4], the active hydroxyl and amino groups make MEA molecules highly reactive ( Scheme 1), and the possible primary reactions include the intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI and vinylamine (VA), the deamination of MEA to acetaldehyde (AcH), and the intermolecular dehydration of MEA to piperazine (PIP). Moreover, the secondary reactions, with or without the participation of MEA, for the intermediates such as EI, PIP, AcH and VA make the reaction network quite complex (Scheme 1). As a result, the development of a selective catalyst for synthesizing EI becomes a challengeable work. As early as in the 1970 s, the Dow Company has patented several solid catalysts for the MEA to EI reaction, including oxides such as WO3, Nb2O5 and Ta2O5 [6] and mixed metal oxides of Nb, Fe, and Cr or Ta, Fe, and Cr [7,8]. Later patents disclose that both acidic Nb2O5/Ta2O5 and basic BaO supported on SiO2, SiO2-Al2O3, or SiC are selective for EI [9–11]. These patent results suggest that the coexistence of acidic and basic sites seems to play a key role in determining the EI selectivity. By using alkali-exchanged zeolites as catalysts for the MEA to EI reaction, a synergetic effect between acidic and basic sites is proposed to be an important factor in determining the EI selectivity [12]. Moreover, the formations of PIP, triethylenediamine (TEDA), pyrazine (PY), and the alkyl substituents are dependent on the stronger acidic sites over the catalysts, whereas the formation of AcH is determined by the basicity of the catalysts, originated from the higher reactivity of the amino group in MEA molecules with the basic sites. Nippon Shokubai [13–15] has made significant efforts to explore the catalytic roles of acidic and basic sites in the MEA to EI reaction. By screening a series of oxides and mixed oxides, tailoring the strength of acidic/basic sites to an extremely weak level is suggested to be another key factor for EI formation. Among them, SiO2 modified by Cs/P oxides exhibits an excellent catalytic performance with a MEA conversion of 70.1% and an EI selectivity of 78.7% [4]. such as 1-aziridineethanol (AE) formed from the condensation of EI and AcH (Scheme 1) are detectable ever over the catalysts with weaker acidic/basic sites [16–18]. However, 1-aziridineethanol (AE) formed from the condensation of EI and AcH (Scheme 1) are detectable over the Cs/P oxides modified zeolites with weaker acidic/basic sites [16–18]. If the referenced results are comparatively analyzed, a synergetic effect between the acidic and basic sites and their strength are speculated to play an important role in achieving selective dehydration of MEA to EI. However, the catalytic performance over the reported catalysts is still unsatisfactory due to the side reactions that occur simultaneously. The reason can be attributed to the lack of detailed insights into the impacts of the amounts of acidic/basic sites on the catalytic performance. Therefore, it is still necessary to systematically tailor the acidity or basicity of the employed catalysts and to quantitatively correlate this acidity or basicity with their catalytic performance in the MEA to EI reaction. The abundance, cheapness, and environmental compatibility have made the naturally occurred clay as a material of the 21st century [19,20]. Taking the widely distributed montmorillonite (MMT) as an example, the simple acid activation of MMT (Acid-MMT), i.e., the treatment of MMT with an inorganic liquid acid such as nitric acid, can modify the acidity/basicity in a wide range [21–23]. The versatile and facile tailoring in acidity/basicity and porosity by a simple acid activation makes Acid-MMT an effective catalyst or support for acid-base cooperative catalysis. In our previous work [24], we considered acid-activated montmorillonite (Acid-MMT) as a catalyst for the MEA dehydration to EI. However, the catalytic activity is found to be low. This study aims to improve the catalytic performance of Acid-MMT by modification with acidic and basic oxides and optimization of the preparation conditions. The physicochemical properties of the modified catalysts are characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, and temperature programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) and CO2 (CO2-TPD). The impacts of amount, strength, and balance of the acidic and basic sites on the conversion and product selectivity are investigated by correlating the catalytic evaluations with characterizations and a statistical study. Consequently, this work reveals the importance of the amount, strength, and balance of the acidic and basic sites in determining the product selectivity of the MEA conversion, which proposes necessary evidences for the design of effective solid acids/bases catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O (AR, ≥ 98.0%), Yb(NO3)3·6 H2O (AR, ≥ 99.9%), La(NO3)3·6 H2O (AR, ≥ 99.0%), Ba(NO3)2 (AR, ≥ 99.0%), NaNO3 (AR, ≥ 99.0), KNO3 (AR, ≥ 98.5), CsNO3 (AR, ≥ 99.9%), Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O (AR, ≥ 98.5%), Al(NO3)3·9 H2O (AR, ≥ 99.0%), (NH4)3PO4·3 H2O (AR, ≥ 95.0%) and H3BO3 (AR, ≥ 99.8%) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Na-type montmorillonite (AR, ≥ 98%) was purchased from Zhejiang sanding Technology Co., Ltd. Monoethanolamine (AR, ≥ 98%) was purchased from Fushun North Chemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Acid-MMT was obtained by treating the Na-type montmorillonite at 104 °C in a solution of 3.2 mol L−1 HNO3 for 24 h and by calcining at 850 °C for 4 h. The modified Acid-MMT catalysts were prepared via the wet impregnation method described previously [24]. Typically, 2 mmol of (NH4)3PO4·3 H2O and an equivalent mole of basic species such as Zn(NO3)2, Yb(NO3)3, La(NO3)3, Ba(NO3)2, NaNO3, KNO3 or CsNO3 were separately dissolved in deionized water by stirring at room temperature. 3 g Acid-MMT was then slowly added into the solution by stirring and then impregnating at room temperature for 12 h. The impregnated catalysts were dried at 120 °C for 8 h and calcinated at 850 °C for 4 h under a flow of dry air with heating rate of 2 °C·min−1, then crushed and sieved to obtain the required particle with size of 20 − 40 mesh. The obtained sample was abbreviated as X-P2O5/Acid-MMT, where X was the nature of the basic species. For comparison, 2 mmol of CsNO3 and an appropriate mole of acidic species such as Fe(NO3)3·9 H2O, Al(NO3)3·9 H2O, (NH4)3PO4·3 H2O and H3BO3 were separately incorporated onto 3 g Acid-MMT to prepare the Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT sample under the same conditions, where Y was the nature of the acidic species. Acid-MMT modified by P2O5 or Cs2O was prepared according to the same wet impregnation method by adding 2 mmol of (NH4)3PO4·3 H2O or 2 mmol of CsNO3, and the obtained sample was abbreviated as P2O5/Acid-MMT and Cs2O/Acid-MMT, respectively. Acid-MMT modified by a fixed amount of CsNO3 (2 mmol) and a various amount of (NH4)3PO4·3 H2O and calcinated at 850 °C was prepared according to the same wet impregnation method and designated as Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850, where m refers to the molar ratio of P2O5 to Cs2O (m = 0, 0.33, 0.55, 0.75, 1.0, 1.2 and 1.63). Acid-MMT modified by Cs2O and P2O5 with a fixed P2O5/Cs2O molar ratio of 1.0 was calcinated at different temperatures (T = 450, 650, 750, 850, 950, 1050 and 1150 °C), which was designated as Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T. 2.3 Characterization techniques and calculation method XRD patterns were measured at room temperature on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer equipped with a monochromatized CuKα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation source at 40 kV and 40 mA and silicon array detectors. The catalysts were pressed into flat discs (Ø = 2 mm, thickness of 1 mm) in a homemade mold. The patterns were recorded for 2θ angles between 15° and 40° at a step size of 0.02° and a counting time of 0.2 s per step. The specific surface area and total pore volume were obtained from nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at − 196 °C on a BelSorp-Max (Bel Japan, Inc.) measurement. Prior to the analysis, the sample (0.15 g) was degassed at 300 °C for 10 h. The specific surface area was calculated by the BET method. The total pore volume was estimated with the amount of nitrogen adsorbed at the P/P0 = 0.99. The profiles of NH3- and CO2-TPD were measured on a Micromeritics Autochem 2920 instrument. Typically, the sample (0.3 g) was firstly pretreated at 550 °C under a flow of He for 60 min and then was cooled to 120 °C for NH3-TPD and 100 °C for CO2-TPD measurements, respectively. Specially, for the sample that had been calcined at 450 °C, the pretreatment was taken at 450 °C. Subsequently, 10% NH3/He or 10% CO2/He was switched to perform the absorption of NH3 or CO2 for 60 min. After this, the system was purged for 1 h with a flow of He at the same temperature. Finally, the desorption of NH3 (or CO2) was started from 120 (or 100) to 550 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 under a He flow of 30 mL min−1. The amounts of acidic and basic sites are calculated based on the quantity of desorbed NH3 and CO2. To obtain the quantity of desorption, the peak area in the chosen temperature range in a TPD profile is calculated by integration method. Subsequently, the peak area for certain amount of CO2 or NH3 (0.05 mL in this work) is obtained through simple injection using a loop valve. Therefore, the quantity of desorbed NH3 and CO2 can be determined by correlating the peak area in the TPD profile to the peak area obtained during the injection. Thermodynamic analysis was conducted by a Gibbs reactor with the Aspen Plus software. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation Heterogeneous dehydration of MEA to EI was carried out in a vertical fixed-bed tubular quartz reactor (inner diameter = 10 mm) and mounted in a cylindrical electrical furnace. The catalyst bed (ca. 2.0 g, 20 −40 mesh) was sandwiched in the middle of the reactor with quartz wool. A bed of quartz sands was placed above the catalyst in order to completely vaporize the liquid feed. Reaction temperature was measured by a K-type thermocouple sheathed in a quartz capillary tube, which was inserted in the reactor and had direct contact with the quartz wool immediately under the catalyst. The reaction carrier gas was N2, which was co-fed with aqueous MEA. If it was not specified, the reaction was performed under the condition of 420 °C, 0.1 MPa, gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 5000 h−1, and volumetric N2/MEA ratio of 19. Effluents from the reactor were condensed in an ethanol bath kept at − 15 °C and collected hourly for analysis. The condensates were analyzed by GC (GC-9560, Shanghai Huaai chromatographic analysis Co., Ltd.) equipped with an HP-1 column (60 m × 0.32 mm × 1.0 µm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). Moreover, mass spectroscopy is employed to analyze the products with quite low amount. To note, these products with quite low selectivity (<3%), such as PY, AcH, VA, ethylamine (EA), acetonitrile (AcN) and the rest heavy products are together labelled as other products (Others). The conversion of MEA was calculated with Eq. (1). The selectivity of specific product was calculated based on the carbon atom with Eq. (2). The yield of product was calculated with Eq. (3). (1) MEA Conversion = [ F MEA ] inlet − [ F MEA ] outlet [ F MEA ] inlet × 100 % (2) Selectivity of product = n i × [ F i ] outlet 2 × ( [ F MEA ] inlet − [ F MEA ] outlet ) × 100 % (3) Yield of product i = ni × [ F i ] outlet 2 × [ F MEA ] inlet × 100 % In these equations, F MEA and F i are the volumetric flow rates of MEA and specific product i, respectively. n i is the carbon number of the specific product i. To approach the reaction pathways, selectivity and yield of grouped products formed from different reactions in Scheme 1 were also involved and calculated as the summary of the corresponding specific products. Typically, the grouped products from the intramolecular dehydration reaction included EI, VA, EA, AcN and half of AE; the grouped products from the intermolecular dehydration reaction included PIP, TEDA, PY and their alkyl substituent; the grouped products from the deamination reaction included AcH and the other half of AE. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic results 3.1.1 Effect of acid/base promoters To optimize the promoters, a series of basic oxides (the order of basicity: ZnO < Yb2O3 < La2O3 < BaO < Na2O < K2O < Cs2O) and a series of acidic oxides (the order of acidity: Fe2O3 < Al2O3 < B2O5 < P2O5) are employed to modify Acid-MMT. The results of catalytic evaluations over these catalysts are present in Fig. 1. In Fig. 1a, the conversion of MEA slightly decreases from 100% to 85% with increasing the basicity of the basic oxides. In the case of the selectivity, over those catalysts modified by weakly basic oxides, e.g. ZnO, Yb2O3 and La2O3, no desired EI is produced while PIP + TDEA are more formed [12,25,26]. Subsequently, a considerable formation of EI is observed in spite that PIP and TDEA are principal over BaO and Na2O modified catalysts. Furthermore, the Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst with the strongest basic oxide of Cs2O exhibits an increasing EI selectivity of > 80% and an inhibited selectivity of PIP, TDEA and AE. Hence, increasing the basicity of the incorporated basic oxides leads to the decreasing MEA conversion and PIP + TDEA selectivity, while EI selectivity increases. Fig. 1b shows the catalytic performance of Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts modified by various acidic oxides. We observe that except for the Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst, AE produced from the condensation of EI and AcH is dominated over the other catalysts. The selectivity of PIP + TEDA over the Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts is much lower than over the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalysts in Fig. 1a. Together with the highest EI selectivity of 80.3% and a higher MEA conversion of 86.4% over the Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst, it is suggested that the coexisting of acidic P2O5 and basic Cs2O on Acid-MMT can positively affect the conversion of MEA to EI. For comparison, Acid-MMT modified by Cs2O or P2O5 (Cs2O/Acid-MMT or P2O5/Acid-MMT) were prepared, and the catalytic performance was presented in Fig. S1. We can observe that AE is the predominant product over the Cs2O/Acid-MMT. However, the P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst favors the formations of PIP and TDEA as well as Others. These results indicate that the loading of only either pure P2O5 as an acidic component or Cs2O for basic sites over Acid-MMT cannot selectively convert MEA to EI. 3.1.2 Effect of P2O5/Cs2O ratio and calcination temperature As P2O5 and Cs2O are found to be the optimized modifiers, the molar ratio of P2O5 to Cs2O (P2O5/Cs2O) employed during the catalyst preparation is varied and the corresponding results of catalytic evaluations are shown in Fig. 2a. The MEA conversion significantly increases from 17% to 100% with increasing m from 0 to 1.63. Moreover, the EI selectivity exhibits a volcano-type trend in varying m. The maximum EI selectivity of 80.3% appears when m is equal to 1.0. In the case of byproducts, the selectivity of AE gradually decreases and the selectivity of PIP + TEDA increases with increasing m. These results indicate that the balance between acidic and basic sites over the catalysts can significantly affect the product selectivity in the MEA conversion. Moreover, the effect of calcination temperature (T) is also taken into account, and the results are presented in Fig. 2b. The MEA conversion gradually decreases from 100% to 35% with the increasing T from 450 to 1150 °C. The selectivity of EI and AE increases and the selectivity of PIP and TEDA decreases with increasing T from 450° to 850°C. However, the product selectivity is gradually levelled off if T is further increased until 1150 °C. A summary of typical catalytic results for the heterogeneous dehydration of MEA to EI reaction was also listed in Table S1. As compared with the reported results, the screened Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalyst showed an excellent catalytic performance for EI formation via the heterogeneous dehydration of MEA. Fig. 3 shows the selectivity of grouped products over the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 (Fig. 3a) and Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T (Fig. 3b) catalysts. We can observe that the intermolecular dehydration reaction is promoted with lower m and higher T. However, the selectivity of the deamination reaction significantly decreases with increasing m. The selectivity of the intramolecular dehydration reaction exhibits a volcano-type trend with varying m of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts, meanwhile, higher m promotes the intermolecular dehydration reaction while lower m promotes the deamination reaction. To note, the intramolecular dehydration reaction is always dramatic with T higher than 850 °C. As a result, the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalyst is optimized according to the results of catalytic evaluation. 3.1.3 Effects of reaction conditions The reaction conditions for the MEA conversion are also optimized over the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalyst and the results are present in Fig. 4. As expected, increasing the reaction temperature from 350 to 480 °C results in a significant increase in the MEA conversion from 7.5% to 98.8% (Fig. 4a). In the case of the EI selectivity, a volcano-type trend with different reaction temperatures is observable and the maximum EI selectivity is 80.3% at 420 °C. With the increasing reaction temperature from 350 to 480 °C, the selectivity of AE, PIP, and TEDA gradually decreases. Finally, it is observable that most of the side reactions are inhibited when the reaction temperature is around 420 °C. Fig. 4b shows the effect of GHSV on the catalytic performance. Increasing GHSV from 2500 to 8000 h−1 results in a decreasing MEA conversion from 89.5% to 72.3%. When the GHSV increases from 2500 to 5000 h−1, the EI selectivity gradually increases, and then it is almost levelled off with GHSV higher than 5000 h−1. Moreover, the AE selectivity decreases and the EI selectivity with increasing GHSV, indicating that long contract time improves the AE formation and inhibits the EI formation. This is consistent with the fact that EI formed by the intramolecular dehydration reaction is a primary product while AE is a secondary product (Scheme 1). Fig. 4c shows the effect of N2/MEA ratio in gas feed on the catalytic performance. An increasing MEA conversion from 76.5% to 86.4% is observed with increasing N2/MEA ratio from 5 to 19. However, the MEA conversion then decreases to 79.2% with the ratio further increases to 30. The selectivity of EI increases while the selectivity of AE, PIP, TEDA and other products decreases with increasing N2/MEA ratio from 5 to 19, and then they are almost levelled off with a further increase in the N2/MEA ratio. When both conversion and selectivity are considered, the optimized N2/MEA ratio should be equal to 19. To conclude, the results of catalytic evaluation indicate that the best catalytic performance over the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalyst exhibits under the reaction conditions of reaction temperature = 420 °C, GHSV = 5000 h−1 and N2/MEA = 19. 3.2 Characteristics of the catalysts 3.2.1 Crystal structure Fig. 5 presents XRD patterns of the X-mY/Acid-MMT-T catalysts. No peak ascribed to crystalline acidic or basic oxides can be detected on the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT and Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts besides the Yb2O3-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst as shown in Fig. 5a and b, indicating that most of the acidic and basic oxides are in an amorphous nature or highly dispersed on Acid-MMT. The XRD patterns on the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalysts (Fig. 5a) modified by weaker basic oxides, such as ZnO, La2O3, Yb2O3 and BaO, are characteristic of α-quartz phase (JCPDS No. 65–0466: 20.8°, 26.5°, 36.8°). Moreover, sharp and broad diffraction peaks corresponding to α-cristobalite phase (JCPDS No. 39–1425: 21.8°, 35.8°, 44.2°) appear over the catalysts modified by stronger basic oxides, such as Na2O, K2O and Cs2O, suggesting that the crystallinity of α-cristobalite is high and the crystallite sizes are large over these catalysts. The formation of large α-cristobalite particles suggests that the layered structure of Acid-MMT may be destroyed by incorporating strongly basic oxides. In the case of the Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts, the diffraction peaks for the α-cristobalite phase are significantly sharp on the Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst compared to the remaining catalysts (Fig. 5b). This result also indicates that the layered structure of Acid-MMT is most severely damaged when Acid-MMT is modified by Cs and P oxides. The XRD patterns of Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts are mainly characteristic of α-quartz and α-cristobalite phases (Fig. 5c). Moreover, pyrophosphate (Cs4P2O7) phase is also detected on the catalysts with m lower than 0.55. The variation of T produces a significant effect on the crystallinity of the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts (Fig. 5d). For the catalysts with T lower than 750 °C, the signals for the Cs4P2O7 phase are detected, and the α-quartz and α-cristobalite phases are also presented with the poor crystallinity. The other catalysts calcined at a higher temperature exhibit none of the Cs4P2O7 phase and significant α-quartz and α-cristobalite phases. These results indicate that the Cs4P2O7 phase is unstable, and the layered structure of Acid-MMT is damaged with increasing calcination temperature. Although the Cs4P2O7 phase is claimed to be the main active species in the intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI as indicated in the references [17,18], the catalytic results given in Fig. 2a suggest that the catalysts with lower P2O5/Cs2O ratio exhibited lower activity and selectivity for the intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI reaction. In contrast, the catalysts calcinated at a temperature lower than 750 °C give high activity but low selectivity. The Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 was the best performing catalyst for the formation of EI from MEA, but the XRD pattern of the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalyst has no signal for the Cs4P2O7 phase. There may be no the Cs4P2O7 phase formed, or the Cs4P2O7 phase exists in an amorphous nature. Based on the catalytic and XRD results obtained in our work, the catalytic role of the Cs4P2O7 phase in the intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI reaction is still ambiguous. 3.2.2 Textural properties N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the X-mY/Acid-MMT-T catalysts are presented in Fig. 6. The quantitatively textural properties of these catalysts including BET surface area and total pore volume are calculated and shown in Table S2 of supporting information (SI). As shown in Fig. 6, all the X-mY/Acid-MMT-T catalysts show a type IV isotherm together with an H3-type hysteresis loop based on the IUPAC classification [27], indicating that these catalysts are dominated by a mesoporous structure. For the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalysts, N2 uptake decreases and hysteresis loop becomes smaller in the high-pressure region (P/P0 > 0.6) with increasing the basicity of the basic oxides (Fig. 6a), which indicates decreases of surface area and pore volume as confirmed with the results in Table S2. In the case of the Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts, N2 uptake in the high-pressure region (P/P0 > 0.6) gradually decreases and then increases with increasing the acidity of the acidic species (Fig. 6b). Obviously, Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalyst exhibits the lowest N2 uptake and the lowest surface area (Table S2). In Fig. 6c, N2 uptake and hysteresis loop of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts are not obviously changed by changing m. This result can be more directly reflected from the calculated data given in Table S2. Similar BET surface area and total pore volume are obtained irrespective of m of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts. Though all the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts also show a type IV isotherm together with an H3-type hysteresis loop, N2 uptake significantly decreases and hysteresis loop becomes small in the high-pressure region (P/P0 > 0.6) when T increases (Fig. 6d), indicating that calcination may destroy the mesopore structure of the catalysts. In Table S2, the BET surface area and total pore volume of the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts significantly decrease, respectively, from 111 to 6 m2·g−1 and 0.550–0.021 cm3·g−1 with increasing T. 3.2.3 Acid/base properties NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles of the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT and Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts are given in Fig. S2 of SI. In this work, acidic and basic sites over the catalysts are classified as two types: the weaker sites with the desorption temperature in a low range of 120–200 °C; the stronger sites with the desorption temperature in a high range of 200–400 °C. The amounts of acidic and basic sites are presented in Fig. 7a and b. Fig. 7a shows that the amounts of weaker and stronger acidic sites (w-A and s-A) and the amounts of weaker and stronger basic sites (w-B and s-B) over the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT catalysts generally decrease with increasing the basicity of basic oxides. This can be attributed to that the strong acidity of P2O5 is neutralized by the stronger basic oxides. In the case of the Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts, the amounts of w-/s-A and w-/s-B are low (Fig. 7b), which indicates that changing the nature of the acidic oxides hardly impacts the acidity and basicity of Acid-MMT. Specially, the amounts of s-A and s-B over Cs2O-P2O5/Acid-MMT are higher than those over the catalysts modified by other acidic oxides. NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 and Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts are shown in Fig. S3 of SI, and the quantified results are given in Fig. 8. Similar to the X-P2O5/Acid-MMT and Cs2O-Y/Acid-MMT catalysts, the acidic and basic sites over these catalysts are classified as the weaker and stronger ones. Over the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts (Fig. 8a), the amounts of s-A and s-B slightly increase with increasing m from 0 to 1.0, and then significantly increase when m exceeds 1.0. Moreover, a shift of peak position from 275° to 350°C for the peak between 200 and 400 °C is observed with increasing m, indicating that the strength of s-A and s-B becomes stronger (Fig. S3a and b). The amount of Cs oxide is fixed, and the textural properties of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts are not obviously changed by increasing m. Therefore, the increasing amount and strength of s-A and s-B over the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts can be reasonably attributed to the increased P oxide. For w-A and w-B, the amounts of them increase with increasing m from 0 to 1.0, and then decrease when m exceeds 1.0, which may be related to the excessive P oxide. However, it is difficult to clearly explain the effects of P oxide on the acid/base properties of the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 catalysts based on the present characterization results. As indicated in the references [28–31], the acidic sites over the Cs-P modified catalysts are the Cs and P cations, and the basic sites are the O anion, which mainly originates from Cs and P precursors, Cs and P oxides, and cesium phosphates (e.g. CsPO3, Cs4P2O7 and Cs3PO4). However, a clear description of the strength of the acidic and basic sites generated from different species is difficult to obtain due to the complex interactions of the Cs/P species with different supports. In the case of Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts with fixed Cs2O and P2O5 amounts, the quantified results in Fig. 8b show that the amounts of w-/s-A and w-/s-B significantly decrease with increasing the calcination temperature from 450 to 1150 °C. These results are clearly observed from the NH3- and CO2-TPD profiles of the Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts presented in Fig. S2c and d. These results can be explained in the following two parts. On one hand, Cs and P species are not completely decomposed at the calcination temperature below 650 °C, which provide numerous acidic and basic sites. As the Cs and P species gradually decompose with increasing T from 650 to 1150 °C, the amounts of acidic and basic sites on these catalysts gradually decrease. On the other hand, the dramatic variation of textual and structural properties of Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts with increasing T may be also responsible for the decrease in amounts of acidic and basic sites. The results of XRD and nitrogen adsorption-desorption have indicated that the layered structure of Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T can be gradually destroyed with increasing T and re-aggregates in the dense forms of α-quartz and α-cristobalite phases. As the results, the acidic and basic sites may be encapsulated in the bulk phase during the calcination process. 4 Discussion 4.1 Thermodynamics of the MEA dehydration As stated in the section of introduction, the reactions involved in the gas-phase MEA conversion are very complex, and the products of which are significantly affected by the reaction conditions. Thus, the thermodynamics analyses of the reaction system can provide favorable parameters including temperature and pressure for maximizing the targeted product. As an estimation, the thermodynamics of each reaction, i.e., intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI and VA, intermolecular dehydration of MEA to PIP, and deamination of MEA to AcH, are calculated by minimizing the Gibbs free energy of the reaction system. The complete results are presented in Tables S3-S6 of SI and the results of Gibbs free energy (Δr G ϴ) are presented in Fig. 9. From the results in Fig. 9, all the primary reactions can occur spontaneously under the selected condition (380–600 °C). Moreover, Δr G ϴ for EI formed via the intramolecular dehydration reaction is the highest; Δr G ϴ for the intramolecular dehydration of MEA to VA is much lower than the MEA to EI reaction; PIP and AcH from the intermolecular dehydration and deamination reactions, respectively, exhibit the lowest Δr G ϴ . These results indicate that the intermolecular dehydration and deamination reactions of MEA is thermodynamically more favorable than the intramolecular dehydration reaction under the current reaction conditions. The detailed data in Table S3 suggests that high temperature thermodynamically favors intramolecular dehydration of MEA to EI. When the reaction temperature increases up to 580 °C, MEA can be almost completely converted to EI. For the other primary reactions (Tables S4-S6), MEA can be completely converted under the selected reaction temperature range (380–600 °C). Furthermore, irrespective of the product, decreasing pressure is more favorable for the MEA conversion. Thus, the conditions of atmosphere pressure and the high dilution of MEA feed by inert gas are usually employed in industry. According to the thermodynamic results, modifying the kinetic reaction behavior through catalyst design is very necessary to improve the EI formation via the intramolecular dehydration of MEA. 4.2 Key factors in determining the activity of MEA to EI The amount, strength and balance of the acidic and basic sites are essential for achieving selective dehydration of MEA to EI. To insight into the effects of strength and balance, the selectivity for the intramolecular and intermolecular dehydration are plotted with the molar ratio between the strong acidic and basic sites (s-A/B), and the results are present in Fig. 10. With increasing the s-A/B ratio from 0.4 to 0.8 (Fig. 10a), the selectivity for intramolecular dehydration increases, and then keeps unchangeable with further increasing the s-A/B ratio from 0.8 to 1.7. Meanwhile, the selectivity for the intermolecular dehydration decreases with the increase in the s-A/B ratio to 0.8, and then keeps unchangeable with further increasing the ratio from 0.8 to 1.7 (Fig. 10b). These results indicate that a balanced s-A/B ratio plays an important role in the selective intramolecular dehydration of MEA, which is consistent with the results reported in the literatures [4,12]. Unexpectedly, the selectivity for intermolecular dehydration of MEA is not increased when s-A/B ratio is high, which is different from the results reported in the literatures [4,12]. For the weaker sites, no simple correlation between the ratio of weaker acidic to basic sites (w-A/B) and the selectivity of grouped products can be obtained (Fig. S4). The yield of EI is also plotted with s-A/B and w-A/B ratios over the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 and Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts in Fig. 11. The highest EI yield is found with s-A/B ratio of around 0.8. Neither excessive stronger acidic sites nor stronger basic sites is conducive to the generation of EI. To improve the activity of intramolecular dehydration of MEA and the yield of EI, the groups of -NH2 and -OH in the MEA molecular need to be equally activated. As -NH2 and -OH are respectively activated by the acidic and basic sites, the balanced dispersion of acids and bases should be important. The EI yield reaches maximum when the amount ratio of strong acidic to basic sites is close to 1 (Fig. 11), which well indicate that the balanced dispersion of acids and bases is important to improve the intramolecular dehydration of MEA. Combing the results obtained from Fig. 10a, a low selectivity for the intramolecular dehydration reaction leads to a low EI yield when the s-A/B ratio is lower than 0.8, but a low activity for the intramolecular dehydration reaction is the reason for a low EI yield when the s-A/B ratio is higher than 0.8. In contrast, no simple relation between the EI yield and w-A/B ratio is observed as seen in Fig. 11b. The observations obtained from Fig. S4 and Fig. 11b are different from the results reported by H. Tsuneki, who claims that the extremely weak acidic and basic sites are essential for the selective formation of EI from MEA. The amounts of acidic and basic sites are also directly correlated with the MEA conversion and product selectivity, and the results are presented in Fig. 12. Not unexpectedly, the MEA conversion increases with increasing the amounts of w-/s-A and w-/s-B, and thereafter stabilizes at 100% with further increase (Fig. 12a). These results are consistent with those in the previous references [12]. In the case of selectivity, a high selectivity of EI is only obtained when the amounts of both w-/s-A and w-/s-B are low (Fig. 12b). Moreover, the selectivity of AE exhibits a similar trend as the selectivity of EI (Fig. 12c). This is because AE is the secondary product from the condensation of EI and AcH. On the contrary, the selectivity of PIP + TEDA increases with increasing the amounts of w-/s-A and w-/s-B (Fig. 12d). It is noteworthy that irreversible of the strength of the acidic/basic sites exhibit the same effects on the catalytic performance. The amounts of acidic/basic sites over the Cs2O-mP2O5/Acid-MMT-850 and Cs2O-1.0 P2O5/Acid-MMT-T catalysts are also correlated with the selectivity of grouped products ( Fig. 13). Irrespective of the strength, increasing the amounts of acidic/basic sites leads to a decrease in the selectivity for the intramolecular dehydration and deamination of MEA but an increase in the selectivity for the intermolecular dehydration. These results indicate that the low amounts of acidic/basic sites are always beneficial for the intramolecular dehydration and deamination of MEA. However, the selectivity for the intermolecular dehydration can be significantly inhibited when the amounts of acidic/basic sites are low. These results are consistent with the results obtained from Fig. 12. Based on these understandings, we can speculate that the low amounts of acidic and basic sites favor the formation of EI and AcH, while the formation of PIP, TEDA and PY via the intermolecular dehydration is favorable with the increasing amounts. On one hand, the low amounts of acidic/basic sites lead to a poor adsorption of MEA, which prefers to a monomolecular reaction, such as the intramolecular dehydration and deamination of MEA. On the other hand, the increasing amounts of acidic and basic sites can improve the concentration of MEA on the catalyst surface, resulting in the increase in both the MEA conversion and the selectivity for the unwanted poly-molecule intermolecular dehydration. Based on these results, the similar selectivity for the intramolecular dehydration of a high value in the range of the s-A/B ratio from 0.8 to 1.7 (Fig. 10a) can be attributed to the low amounts of acidic and basic sites over these catalysts. Importantly, the key role of the amounts of acidic and basic sites in determining the distribution of products from MEA conversion has not been reported in the literature. 4.3 Statistical analyses A statistical study is realized by response surface analysis (RSA) with software of Design Expert 8.0. More Acid-MMT based catalysts with different acidity and basicity are prepared by the same methods as noted in Section 2.2. The results of catalytic evaluations (Table S7) and amounts of acidic/basic sites (Table S8) are presented in SI. Subsequently, the amounts of weaker/stronger/total acidic and basic sites (w-/s-/t-A and w-/s-/t-B), the selectivity and yield of the grouped products are involved in RSA. Methods and results (Table S9) of RSA are also shown in the SI. The RSA results (Table S9) indicate that no reasonable relation can be obtained between the selectivity of MEA deamination and the amounts of acidic/basic sites. For the products from the intramolecular and intermolecular dehydration, a linear relation is found to be suitable for correlating the selectivity or yield with the amounts of acidic/basic sites. The s-A exhibits a significant effect on irrespective of selectivity and yield of the grouped products, while the effect of w-A is insignificant. However, in the case of basicity, the w-B exhibits a more significant effect than the s-B. Furthermore, with the increase in the amounts of s-A and w-A, the selectivity and yield for the intermolecular dehydration increase, while the selectivity for the intramolecular dehydration decreases (Fig. S5). Similarly, with increasing the amount of s-B and decreasing the amounts of w-B, the selectivity and yield for the intramolecular dehydration increase but the selectivity for the intermolecular dehydration decreases. These results are consistent with the fact that the intramolecular and intermolecular dehydration are parallel reactions in the MEA conversion, which can also confirm the conclusion obtained from Fig. 13. Therefore, unsurprisingly, we can observe totally reversed trends of the intramolecular and intermolecular dehydration as the function of the amounts of t-A and t-B drawn in Fig. S5. Moreover, it is interesting to obtain the quadratic fitting models for the yield of the intramolecular and intermolecular dehydration ( Fig. 14). When the amounts of acidic and basic sites increase together, the yield for the intramolecular dehydration is improved. The intermolecular dehydration, however, is improved when the acidic (or basic) sites are more numerous. These results are consistent with those obtained from Figs. 10 and 11, indicating that the balance between acidic and basic sites is also one of key factors for the intramolecular dehydration of MEA and the EI formation. 5 Conclusion This work demonstrates that over the oxides modified Acid-MMT, the catalytic performance of the MEA dehydration can be regulated by varying the catalyst composition (nature and ratio of the acidic and basic modifiers) and the calcination temperature. The basic Cs2O and acidic P2O5 are found to be the optimized modifiers and an excellent EI formation (EI selectivity of 80.3% and MEA conversion of 84.6%) is obtained with a P2O5/Cs2O molar ratio of 1.0 and a calcination temperature of 850 °C under the optimized reaction conditions (420 °C, 5000 h−1, N2/MEA 19). Based on correlating the product selectivity with acidity and basicity, we can speculate that EI from the intramolecular dehydration of MEA is improved due to the lower and more balanced amounts of acidic and basic sites. When thermodynamic parameters and kinetic pathway are concerned, over the modified Acid-MMT catalysts with the lower and more balanced amounts of acidic and basic sites, the parallel intermolecular dehydration of MEA is kinetically obstructed while the intramolecular dehydration of MEA is improved despite its thermodynamic disadvantage. Therefore, this work carefully reveals the effects of the amount, balance and strength of the acidic and basic sites on the product selectivity, which are important for guiding the development of the high-performance solid acid/bases. coredata.dc:description: The heterogeneous dehydration of monoethanolamine (MEA) to ethylenimine (EI) over solid acids/bases has garnered significant attention in industry because of the importance of EI in fine chemical engineering and the advantage in product separation. Unfortunately, lacking insight into the impacts of acidity/basicity on product selectivity in the reaction hinders the development of high-performance solid acids/bases. To investigate the effect of acidity/basicity, this work employs acid-activated montmorillonite (Acid-MMT) as catalyst and the acidity/basicity is adjusted by adding different acidic/basic oxides and changing preparation conditions. Under the conditions of reaction temperature = 420 °C, GHSV = 5000 h−1, N2/MEA = 19, the optimized Acid-MMT based catalyst modified by Cs2O and P2O5 exhibits a MEA conversion of 86.4% and an EI selectivity of 80.3%. By correlating the catalyst performance with the acidity/basicity, lower amount of acidic/basic sites leads to a higher selectivity of EI via intramolecular dehydration of MEA, while intermolecular dehydration of MEA is inhibited. This is because the intermolecular dehydration reaction is kinetically obstructed by the low acidic/basic amounts, and the parallel intramolecular dehydration reaction becomes kinetically dominated. Furthermore, the catalytic results and the statistical study demonstrate that more balanced amounts between acidic and basic sites favor the intramolecular dehydration reaction. Therefore, we can obtain an effective Cs-P/Acid-MMT catalyst for the selective dehydration of MEA to EI, and propose some solid evidences about the effect of acidity/basicity on product distribution in MEA dehydration over the solid acids/bases.
coredata.dc:title: Regulation of acidity and basicity of oxide/montmorillonite catalysts for selective dehydration of monoethanolamine to ethylenimine
